title: Turbo castanea
text:
Turbo castanea, common names chestnut turban, chestnut turban snail-brown and cat eye snail, is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="sea%20snail">sea snail</a>, marine <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Turbinidae">Turbinidae</a>.
Distribution.
Distribution of "Turbo castanea" include: Aruba, Belize, Bonaire, Caribbean Sea, Cayman Islands, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Curaçao, Gulf of Mexico, Hispaniola, Jamaica, Mexico, Panama, Puerto Rico, Venezuela.; in the Atlantic Ocean from North Carolina to Brazil.
Description.
The maximum recorded <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> length is 55 mm.
This is an abundant species that is variable both in color and the prominence of the <a href="Sculpture%20%28mollusc%29">sculpture</a>. The solid, imperforate shell has an ovate-conic shape. It is orange-colored, brown or gray, sometimes banded, flammulated, or maculated with white or brown. The conic <a href="Spire%20%28mollusc%29">spire</a> is acute. The <a href="Suture%20%28anatomy%29">suture</a> is subcanaliculate. The 5-6 convex <a href="Whorl%20%28mollusc%29">whorl</a>s are somewhat flattened in the middle. They are ornamented with numerous unequal spiral granose, spinose or squamose <a href="Lira%20%28mollusc%29">lira</a>e, of which the subsutural and three or four submedian are more prominent. The typical form is very sharply sculptured, the principal lirae occasionally bearing vaulted scales. The white <a href="Aperture%20%28mollusc%29">aperture</a> is subcircular, and subangular above. There is no <a href="Umbilicus%20%28mollusc%29">umbilicus</a>. The <a href="Peristome%20%28gastropod%29">peristome</a> is slightly produced below. The <a href="Columella%20%28gastropod%29">columella</a> has a heavy white callus.
The <a href="Operculum%20%28gastropod%29">operculum</a> is castaneous within, with four rapidly increasing whorls. Its nucleus is one-third the distance across the face. The outer surface is convex and nearly smooth. It is white, or stained with brown and green around the middle.
Habitat.
Minimum recorded depth is 0 m. Maximum recorded depth is 141 m.
